Description:
The general theory of relativity describes gravity in a completely different way than classical physics does: In general relativity, gravity is not described as a force but rather as the interplay between mass, time, and space. When Einstein published his theory in 1915, he predicted several surprising phenomena which were later experimentally confirmed – among them the bending of light and warping of time by massive objects.

This learning resource was developed by the research and development team in the project ReleQuant, based at the University of Oslo, the Norwegian Centre for Science Education, and the Norwegian University of Science and Technology. Magdalena Kersting has been responsible for the development of the program. It has received support from the Research Council of Norway and the Olav Thon Foundation.
Curriculum links:
- gravity
- general relativity
- astronomy
- nature of science
- history of science

Domain: Gravitational Waves; Special and General Relativity
Description: Website providing modular, illustrated introductory texts that introduce the fundamentals and most important applications of Einstein's theories of special and of general relativity.
Author/Originator: Max Planck Institute for Gravitational Physics (Albert Einstein Institute)
Curriculum links: special relativity, fields and forces, gravity

Resource Name: Frontiers project: Teaching modern physics in school curricula
Type of Resource: Collection; Online; Reading; Video; Worksheet; Lesson Plan
Description: This project contains a set of "demonstrators" for teaching modern physics in high school. The demonstrators provide the targeted age, a short description and several teaching material.
Author/Originator: Several authors from various countries (see demonstrators webpage)

Description: The LIGO Educator's Guide includes two classroom ready activities: building pulsar models that can then  be used to demonstrate coalescence, and a binary coalescence version of the classic warped spacetime demo made from spandex. Also background information explaining Newtonian vs. Einsteinian gravity as well as a description of the Nobel prize-winning discovery of GW150914.

Resource Name: Build and Use a Simple Spectroscope

Description: A range of classroom activities created by the LIGO community
Summaries of the LIGO science and technology explained for a general audience
A workshop exploring gravitational waves and their detection, through both practical and theorectical activities
Curriculum links: Waves; Interference; Resonance; Trigonometry; Numeracy; Gravitational Waves;

Description: Can you detect a gravitational wave? In Black Hole Hunter, your objective is to listen to gravitational wave detector data and determine whether or not you can hear the given gravitational wave signal in the sound file, or whether it is just noise.
Curriculum links: Black Holes; Gravitational Waves; Fun Learning

Description: LIGO is by no means the first experiment to detect black holes, with x-ray measurements suggesting their presence. This simple web-tool compares the sizes and masses of known black holes.
Curriculum links: Black Holes; Gravitational Waves; Scientific Data

Description: The LIGO measurements reveal an awful lot about the black holes in the detected systems. This web-tool allows you to explore what we know in the form of an interactive graph.
Based on Chromoscope, Gravoscope shows the locations on the sky that detected gravitational waves originated.

Resource Name: Searching for Gravitational Waves in Noisy Data
Description:
A range of educational resources relating to gravitational waves:
  • Searching for Gravitational Waves in Noisy Data (PSU)
  • Hands-on Gravitational Wave Astronomy: Extraction of Astrophysical Information from Simulated Signals (PSU)
  • Various other LIGO Classroom Activities

Resource Name: Hands-on Gravitational Wave Astronomy: Extraction of Astrophysical Information from Simulated Signals

Description: A range of classroom activities created by the LIGO community
Summaries of the scientific papers published about on LIGO/Virgo science and technology, but explained for a more general audience

A range of apps designed and built by gravitational wave researchers to explore the science and technology of gravitational wave detection:
  • Pocket Black Hole (play with the light-bending effect of a black hole)
  • Stretch and Squeeze (explore how a passing gravitational wave would stretch and squash the distances between objects)
  • Space Time Quest (A game putting you in charge of designing your own gravitational wave detector)
  • Black Hole Master (a light-hearted remake of the old classic "Pong", except with a cosmic twist!)

This workshop gives students the opportunity to analyse and interpret gravitational wave data. The activity is in two parts, one calculating the distance to the source, and the other determining the redshift. These results are then combined to determine the Hubble constant - the rate of expansion of the Universe.
 
 There are 8 sets of data, so that allows for the possibility of 16 "teams", with pairs of teams using the same dataset.
Curriculum links: Gravitational Waves; Data Anlysis; Waves; Black Holes
